meta.title: Claude Code vs Cursor
meta.subtitle: A Technical Leader's Guide
meta.description: Comprehensive comparison for enterprise decision-makers - security, architecture, economics, and long-term strategy.
meta.author: Engineering Team

slides.title: Claude Code vs Cursor
slides.subtitle: Introduction
slides.content: A technical leader's guide to making the right choice for your organization.
slides.visualContent:
graph TD
    A[AI Coding Tools] --> B[Claude Code]
    A --> C[Cursor]
    B --> D[Client-Side]
    B --> E[Direct to Anthropic]
    C --> F[Server-Side]
    C --> G[Through Cursor Servers]

slides.title: The Enterprise Perspective
slides.subtitle: Introduction
slides.content: This isn't about which tool developers like - it's about architectural decisions that cascade through your entire organization.

items.title: 20+ Companies Evaluated
items.text: Every single one chose Claude Code for enterprise deployment

items.title: Not About 'Better'
items.text: The architectural differences matter for security, cost, and production agents

items.title: Long-Term Strategy
items.text: Your choice today defines your AI infrastructure for years

slides.title: What We'll Cover
slides.subtitle: Agenda
slides.content: The critical factors for enterprise decision-making.

items.title: 1. Architecture
items.text: Where your code actually goes

items.title: 2. Economics
items.text: Why rate limits matter more than you think

items.title: 3. Supply Chain Security
items.text: The elephant in the room

items.title: 4. Gateway Control
items.text: Enterprise audit and compliance

items.title: 5. Production Agents
items.text: Planning for the future

items.title: 6. Decision Framework
items.text: Making the right choice

slides.title: Architecture
slides.subtitle: Where Your Code Goes
slides.content: The most fundamental difference - everything else flows from here.
slides.visualContent:
graph LR
    subgraph Claude Code
        A[Your Machine] -->|Direct| B[Anthropic]
    end
    subgraph Cursor
        C[Your Machine] --> D[Cursor Servers]
        D --> E[LLM Provider]
    end

slides.title: Cursor: Server-Side Processing
slides.subtitle: Architecture
slides.content: All LLM requests route through Cursor's infrastructure.

items.title: Code in Transit
items.text: Every line of code travels through Cursor's servers before reaching the LLM

items.title: Vector Embeddings
items.text: For code retrieval, Cursor performs embeddings on their servers - not temporarily, but ongoing

items.title: Additional Failure Point
items.text: Your code sits on Cursor's servers, waiting in queue

items.title: Limited Control
items.text: Dependent on Cursor's infrastructure and uptime

slides.title: Claude Code: Client-Side Processing
slides.subtitle: Architecture
slides.content: Requests go directly from your machine to Anthropic's models.

items.title: No Intermediate Server
items.text: Just your machine talking to the model - no middle layer

items.title: No Additional Storage
items.text: No code sitting on third-party infrastructure

items.title: Direct Connection
items.text: Faster, more reliable, fewer points of failure

items.title: Gateway Ready
items.text: Can route through your own infrastructure (AWS Bedrock)

slides.title: Architecture Implications
slides.subtitle: Architecture
slides.content: Why this difference matters for enterprises.
slides.visualContent:
graph TD
    A[Architecture Choice] --> B[Data Flow]
    A --> C[Security Model]
    A --> D[Compliance]
    B --> E[Who Sees Your Code?]
    C --> F[Attack Surface]
    D --> G[Audit Capability]

slides.title: The Economics
slides.subtitle: Rate Limits & Pricing
slides.content: Why rate limits matter more than you think.
slides.visualContent:
graph TD
    A[AI-First Developer] --> B{Hits Rate Limits?}
    B -->|Never| C[Probably Not AI-First]
    B -->|Daily| D[Productivity Impact]
    D --> E[Cost Escalation]
    D --> F[Developer Frustration]

slides.title: Cursor's Pricing Reality
slides.subtitle: Economics
slides.content: The $20/month plan comes with limits that experienced developers hit regularly.

items.title: $20/mo Basic
items.text: Rate limits that AI-first developers hit daily

items.title: When You Exceed
items.text: Wait for reset OR switch to pay-per-token pricing

items.title: Team Costs Escalate
items.text: Per-token pricing for a team can escalate very quickly

items.title: Usage Anxiety
items.text: Engineers hesitant to use the tool due to cost concerns

slides.title: Claude Code's Economics
slides.subtitle: Economics
slides.content: Dramatically different value proposition at scale.

items.title: $200/mo Account
items.text: Consistently delivers $5,000+ in equivalent token value

items.title: Why The Difference?
items.text: Anthropic controls the infrastructure end-to-end

items.title: Anthropic's Incentive
items.text: Maximize utilization - servers run 24/7 anyway

items.title: Cursor's Incentive
items.text: Limit usage - they pay Anthropic per API request

slides.title: Real-World Billing Comparison
slides.subtitle: Economics
slides.content: See the difference: Cursor's usage-based costs vs Claude's flat rate.

slides.title: The Unit Economics Problem
slides.subtitle: Economics
slides.content: Why Cursor may struggle to maintain their position long-term.
slides.visualContent:
graph TD
    subgraph Anthropic
        A[Own Infrastructure] --> B[Fixed Costs]
        B --> C[Incentive: More Usage]
    end
    subgraph Cursor
        D[Pays Per Request] --> E[Variable Costs]
        E --> F[Incentive: Limit Usage]
    end

slides.title: Supply Chain Security
slides.subtitle: The Elephant in the Room
slides.content: What every CISO should know about VS Code forks.
slides.visualContent:
graph TD
    A[Cursor] --> B[VS Code Fork]
    B --> C[Cannot Use Microsoft Marketplace]
    C --> D[Uses OpenVSX]
    D --> E[Different Security Posture]
    E --> F[Supply Chain Risk]

slides.title: The VS Code Fork Problem
slides.subtitle: Supply Chain Security
slides.content: Cursor inherits significant supply chain risk from its architecture.

items.title: VS Code License
items.text: Forks are free - but cannot use Microsoft's official marketplace

items.title: OpenVSX Instead
items.text: Cursor uses OpenVSX, an open-source marketplace alternative

items.title: Different Monitoring
items.text: Microsoft doesn't monitor OpenVSX with the same rigor

items.title: Escalating Attacks
items.text: Recent months show increasing supply chain attacks on VS Code marketplaces

slides.title: GlassWorm Attack (Oct 2025)
slides.subtitle: Supply Chain Security
slides.content: A self-propagating worm spreading through VS Code extensions.

items.title: 7 OpenVSX Extensions
items.text: Compromised in just one week

items.title: 35,000+ Downloads
items.text: Before detection occurred

items.title: Expert Assessment
items.text: "One of the most sophisticated supply chain attacks ever analyzed"

items.title: Capabilities
items.text: Credential harvesting, crypto wallet draining, SOCKS proxy deployment

slides.title: Supply Chain Risk Impact
slides.subtitle: Supply Chain Security
slides.content: What this means for organizations using Cursor.

items.title: Additional Security Review
items.text: Every extension needs thorough vetting

items.title: Compromised Environments
items.text: Potential for developer machine compromise

items.title: Credential Theft Risk
items.text: NPM, GitHub, Git credentials at risk

items.title: Compliance Concerns
items.text: Significant issues for regulated industries

slides.title: Gateway Control
slides.subtitle: Enterprise Features
slides.content: Monitoring, auditing, and controlling AI interactions.
slides.visualContent:
graph LR
    A[Engineer Workstation] --> B[Your Gateway]
    B --> C[Monitor Requests]
    B --> D[Validate Content]
    B --> E[Audit Logs]
    B --> F[AWS Bedrock]
    F --> G[Claude Models]

slides.title: AWS Bedrock Integration
slides.subtitle: Gateway Control
slides.content: Claude Code enables enterprise-grade control through private gateways.

items.title: Request Monitoring
items.text: Monitor every request leaving engineer workstations

items.title: Content Validation
items.text: Validate no sensitive company information is sent

items.title: Custom Rate Limiting
items.text: Implement organization-specific access controls

items.title: Audit Logs
items.text: Maintain compliance-ready logs for every interaction

slides.title: Why Gateway Control Matters
slides.subtitle: Gateway Control
slides.content: The architecture determines what's possible.

items.title: Claude Code: Possible
items.text: Client-side requests can be routed through your infrastructure

items.title: Cursor: Not Possible
items.text: Requests go through Cursor servers first - you can't intercept

items.title: Regulated Industries
items.text: Finance, healthcare, government require audit capability

items.title: Not Optional
items.text: For many organizations, this level of control is required - not nice to have

slides.title: Production Agents
slides.subtitle: Planning for the Future
slides.content: Your development tool choice impacts your AI strategy.
slides.visualContent:
graph TD
    A[Claude Code Approval] --> B[Claude SDK Approved]
    B --> C[Same Security Review]
    B --> D[Same Compliance Checks]
    B --> E[Production Agent Ready]
    
    F[Cursor] --> G[Development Tool Only]
    G --> H[Separate Agent Platform Needed]

slides.title: The SDK Advantage
slides.subtitle: Production Agents
slides.content: Claude Code is part of a broader ecosystem.

items.title: Ecosystem Alignment
items.text: Approving Claude Code = approving Claude SDK for production

items.title: Security Transfer
items.text: Security review, compliance checks, architectural decisions all transfer

items.title: Cursor Limitation
items.text: Cursor is a development tool, not a platform for production agents

items.title: Future-Proofing
items.text: Build development AND production on the same foundation

slides.title: The Testing Principle
slides.subtitle: Production Agents
slides.content: Claude Code as your testing ground for production viability.

items.title: The Rule
items.text: If Claude Code can't succeed under full supervision, your production agent won't succeed

items.title: Task Decomposition
items.text: Understand how to break down complex tasks for agents

items.title: Error Modes
items.text: Learn the failure patterns before production

items.title: Edge Cases
items.text: Discover edge cases in a controlled environment

slides.title: Decision Framework
slides.subtitle: Making the Choice
slides.content: Critical factors for enterprise evaluation.
slides.visualContent:
graph TD
    A[Evaluation] --> B[Architecture]
    A --> C[Cost at Scale]
    A --> D[Supply Chain]
    A --> E[Gateway Control]
    A --> F[Production Strategy]
    B --> G[Decision]
    C --> G
    D --> G
    E --> G
    F --> G

slides.title: Critical for Most Organizations
slides.subtitle: Decision Framework
slides.content: The questions every technical leader should answer.

items.title: Architecture Review
items.text: Where does your code go? Who has access to it?

items.title: Cost Modeling
items.text: Calculate costs for your team size at realistic AI-first usage levels

items.title: Supply Chain Assessment
items.text: What's your risk tolerance for marketplace attacks?

items.title: Future Planning
items.text: Are you building production agents? What's your AI strategy?

slides.title: For Regulated Industries
slides.subtitle: Decision Framework
slides.content: Additional considerations for finance, healthcare, government.

items.title: Gateway Control
items.text: Can you monitor and audit all LLM interactions?

items.title: Compliance Requirements
items.text: What certifications and controls do you need?

items.title: Data Residency
items.text: Where is your code processed and stored?

items.title: Audit Trail
items.text: Can you prove compliance to regulators?

slides.title: The Real Decision Pattern
slides.subtitle: Decision Framework
slides.content: What happens when organizations actually evaluate.
slides.visualContent:
graph TD
    A[Initial Attraction to Cursor] --> B[Familiar VS Code]
    A --> C[Easy Onboarding]
    A --> D[Developer Marketing]
    
    E[Reality Check] --> F[Data Flow Analysis]
    E --> G[Cost at Scale]
    E --> H[Supply Chain Risk]
    E --> I[Compliance Needs]
    
    F --> J[Choose Claude Code]
    G --> J
    H --> J
    I --> J

slides.title: Developer Experience Reality
slides.subtitle: Decision Framework
slides.content: What developers actually care about.

items.title: Does It Help?
items.text: Developers care most about actual productivity gains

items.title: No Friction
items.text: They don't want limits and restrictions getting in the way

items.title: Claude Code Delivers
items.text: Generous limits mean engineers rarely hit them during normal work

items.title: When Pushing Limits
items.text: AI-first developers aren't facing unexpected bills or daily caps

slides.title: The Hybrid Question
slides.subtitle: Decision Framework
slides.content: Can you use both tools together?

items.title: Technically Yes
items.text: Claude Code can run inside Cursor via extension

items.title: But Consider
items.text: You still inherit Cursor's supply chain risks

items.title: Gateway Issue
items.text: You can't route Cursor's requests through your infrastructure

items.title: Recommendation
items.text: For enterprise: standardize on Claude Code, use any editor

slides.title: When Cursor Makes Sense
slides.subtitle: Decision Framework
slides.content: Cursor isn't wrong for everyone.

items.title: Individual Developers
items.text: Personal projects without security requirements

items.title: Small Teams
items.text: No strict compliance or audit needs

items.title: Experimentation
items.text: Testing AI coding before enterprise commitment

items.title: VS Code Dependency
items.text: Teams that absolutely require VS Code's specific features

slides.title: The Bigger Question
slides.subtitle: Conclusion
slides.content: This decision is really a proxy for your AI strategy.
slides.visualContent:
graph TD
    A[How Seriously Are You Taking AI-First?] --> B{Strategy}
    B -->|Experiment| C[Choice Matters Less]
    B -->|Core Strategy| D[Foundation Matters]
    D --> E[Security Architecture]
    D --> F[Cost Scaling]
    D --> G[Production Agents]
    D --> H[Long-Term Platform]

slides.title: Strategic Implications
slides.subtitle: Conclusion
slides.content: Your choice today defines your AI infrastructure for years.

items.title: Not About This Week
items.text: Stop asking which tool developers like today

items.title: Think 2-3 Years
items.text: AI-first development will be how your team works

items.title: Foundation Matters
items.text: Development tools evolve into production infrastructure

items.title: Security First
items.text: Architecture, supply chain, and compliance compound over time

slides.title: Key Takeaways
slides.subtitle: Conclusion
slides.content: What technical leaders need to remember.

items.title: Architecture Matters
items.text: Client-side vs server-side determines security posture

items.title: Economics Favor Claude
items.text: Anthropic's unit economics enable generous usage

items.title: Supply Chain Risk
items.text: VS Code forks inherit marketplace vulnerabilities

items.title: Gateway Control
items.text: Only client-side architecture enables enterprise audit

items.title: Production Strategy
items.text: Claude Code aligns development and production platforms

slides.title: The Bottom Line
slides.subtitle: Conclusion
slides.content: Not about better or worse - about fit for your organization.

items.title: Enterprise Requirements
items.text: Security, compliance, audit, scale → Claude Code

items.title: Individual Use
items.text: Personal projects, experimentation → Either tool

items.title: The Pattern
items.text: 20+ companies evaluated, all chose Claude Code for enterprise

slides.title: Final Thought
slides.subtitle: Conclusion
slides.content: The architectural differences matter. A lot.

items.title: Cursor's Tradeoffs
items.text: Made specific decisions to create their product - acceptable for some use cases

items.title: Enterprise Needs
items.text: Security, cost management, supply chain, compliance, audit - these compound

items.title: Make the Right Choice
items.text: Evaluate based on your actual requirements, not developer preferences
